{"step_by_step_thinking": "Agglutination is a reaction that occurs when antibodies bind to antigens on cells, causing the cells to clump together. In the context of blood typing, agglutination indicates the presence of a specific antigen. If antiserum A and antiserum B are added to a blood sample and no agglutination is seen, this means that the blood does not have the A or B antigens, which indicates that the blood type is O. The presence of the Rh factor is determined separately, and in this case, it is stated that the Rh factor is positive. Therefore, the blood type is O positive.", "answer_choice": "A"}
